awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track L: Intelligent Nature-inspired Olfactory Sensors Engineered to Sniff (iNOSES)
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to acquire real-time information about the air we breathe has been brought into the spotlight through recent events and developments, including wildfires, hazardous spills, increasingly stringent emissions regulations, and the identification of specific volatiles in air, spoiled food and diseased breath. However, accurately identifying the composition of gaseous samples typically relies on bulky, expensive and stationary spectroscopic equipment. This Phase I project will introduce a portable chemical gas sensor that relies on artificial intelligence (AI) to provide highly accurate identification of volatiles in real-time. The real-time chemical sensing data will pave the way to standardization in detection and reporting across sectors – a documented challenge leading to poor accountability in emission monitoring, inefficiently timed ventilation and air purification processes, and unnecessary food waste, all of which can have atmospheric, health, and socio-economic impacts. The work will have a significant impact on STEM education, as this highly multidisciplinary project is led by a research team with a strong commitment to outreach, mentorship, and scientific communication. The concepts under investigation range from fluid dynamics, optics, and nanofabrication to AI, building simulations, and methods standardization. This creates many opportunities for research training in different disciplines, allowing students with a wide range of interests and experiences to participate.

The project builds on a relatively simple sensor: a Bragg stack photonic crystal, whose optical reflection spectrum changes upon infiltration by volatiles into its pores. The time-dependence of the spectral shifts is governed by the unique transport dynamics produced by a compound or mixture of compounds and is used to continuously train a machine learning algorithm for classification and physical property prediction of compounds. Unique to this approach, the team introduces and implements olfactory inspired ‘sniffing’ sequences when volatiles are ‘inhaled’ and ‘exhaled’ in specific dynamic patterns that maximize the real-time discriminatory power of the device. Phase 1 research has included 1) prototyping, device miniaturization, and software development for detection of a subset of the target chemicals, 2) device and algorithm optimization for real-time sensing and integration into application-specific domains, guided by a combination of control theory, systems design, and machine learning, and 3) pilot studies in real environments, in partnership with industrial experts. Together, the multidisciplinary theoretical, experimental, and applied team will push the frontier of chemical sensing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of our project is to improve the design of our prototype sensor of volatile chemicals and to  chart a path to its commercialization. To achieve this, several major goals were pursued during this 8 month Phase 1 award, including (1) innovative technology development (hardware and software), (2) team science, and (3) business development including marketing and communications.We conducted over 60 interviews, pivotal to determine our target space of healthy buildings, narrow our initial focus to K-12 schools and LEED O&M buildings, and identify critical indoor pollutants to detect. Based on these outcomes, we developed the SNIFFIA v0-v0.5 prototype series consisting of off-the-shelf chemiresistive sensors capable of detecting and identifying indoor air pollutants, such as toluene and benzene, alongside the standard metrics of temperature, humidity, CO2, and particulate matter. These devices were tested in both a controlled lab environment and a field study in a small office and the resulting data have been used to train specialized machine learning (ML) models. 

During the course of this project, we have been actively engaged in multiple broader impacts initiatives, including mentoring, organizing symposia, and other outreach activities. Our team organized in-person workshops on olfaction, several of which were tailored for teenagers, welcoming 100+ attendees from the general public. We designed and taught the course "Decoding Scentsations - the Science of Smell and Taste," 1 of 7 courses selected in the 2024 class cohort for the Harvard Griffin January Term. We have also mentored 7 undergraduate students from across the United States and Canada. The mentorship provides essential skills to young researchers, from technical capabilities and experimental design to scientific and business communication. The outreach raises public awareness and excites the next generation to pursue science and engineering to make a difference in our world. 

We have presented our work at 4 conferences with a focus on national security, environmental monitoring and toxicology, new developments across chemistry, and new developments in chemical engineering, in the section on emerging sensor technologies. The undergraduate mentees in this project have also presented in symposia, engineering design checkpoint meetings, and to other communities interested in the sensor development. A Perspective paper is currently under review to a peer-reviewed journal, and 2 more journal articles are currently in preparation for submission. We have also produced various informational and marketing materials, such as a logo, pitch deck, website (www.sniffia.com), and video.
